Some of us are hoping for the silent republicans planning to vote for Harris/Walz is larger than anticipated and like Trump surprised Clinton in 2016, Harris shocks MAGA base in 2024. Polls aren't reflecting those folks. Agreed, if Trump does win there will be a bump, but by the end of his term the cycle of a democratic administration having to bail out an economic mess will repeat itself in 2029. Just like with H & W Bush and with Trump 45. Mark my words Quad.
Nice upgrade. We're likely going to get a Trump Bump after November 5 that could take this close to $70. Likely going to lose my shares @ $65.

I look at it differently, not stock price but market value reflects the value better. Normally these go hand in hand but after that strange marketcap reset a few weeks back the ATH market cap and corresponding stock price would be $67.50. I'm confident in the earnings set-up and sentiment but will put in a sell order for a good chunk at $68. Just my view.

You can use a buy and hold strategy and still trade options separately. I have done both.

Modestly successful with using O'Neil's system of buying off "pivot points" from sound bases. The key is then not allowing any one stock to do significant damage by cutting a loss at 8% below the cost basis. To make money in this system you only have to be 'right' in 1 of 3 stock picks. Profits are taken at 20-25%, with exceptions. So for me, mutual funds are the only buy and hold stock market product.
Are you guys that technically follow and trade nutanix successful? Just seems so volatile that it would be a hard to stock to make sense of from that perspective.

I should add (but forgot) that although yesterday (Wednesday) was a non-event, it offered a degree of importance in that the stock price bounced off the longer term support level of $57.25, the rolling 200-day moving average. We'll have to see if that will hold. NTNX's 50-day has been declining which will need to change and is a technical reason why its "wheels are just spinning."
Thanks for explaining this

Jim and Jumbo, because today's volume is going to be less than yesterday it's a non-event despite rising more than 1 1/2%. Yesterday, because of its percentage decline on greater volume than Monday made it a day of distribution. Distinguishing days of accumulation from distribution days and when they're non-events is important to know. And easy to determine.
bigger volume yesterday with bigger loss. This stock just spinning its wheels

No meat on the bone with that 'upgrade.'  Big snooze will wake up if and when the calendar quarter reseller surveys come out by the middle of Oct. BTW, judging by RR's YF interview it appears that he was not hedging the momentum in transformation spending so no worries about falling short of estimates. In the meantime lack of stock momentum and volume can lead to decent size moves either way.

Seeking Alpha upgrades NTNX to a buy and out come the sellers. We're definitely out of favor.

Smartsheet is actually quite comparable to NTNX in terms of growth rate, FCF metrics, and profitability. I'm quite surprised that Private Equity gets away with only paying 6x forward revenue multiple---that's a steal.  NTNX trades now at 6.5x forward revenue, I'm sure a strategic buyer is willing to pay a premium to Smartsheet's 6x due to operational/strategic synergies but their multiple does not bode well for a NTNX acquisition.  The conundrum of NTNX's Monday's marketcap increase of 15% is a killer for the multiple. Still very unclear to me what drove this as a shares increase should be offset by a stock price decrease (issuing shares does not increase the value of the company in itself).
Smartsheet...
AT&T is ditching VMware. it's quite possible they go for a multi-vendor strategy to avoid lock in. Will be a major coup for Nutanix if they get a substantial chunk of the business
Agree. I’m still holding onto a chunk as Bain strike is $65. I sold a lot at $63 as well post earnings.

All they needed to do was be confident, act confidently, and forecast confidently....instead they went conservative and STILL have not recovered.....this stock should be at $80 right now....and trending even higher.I still think it gets there.

Sold 65 calls yesterday and also sold 10 put contracts for 10/18 expiration. Both with a strike at $65. If shares get called away, I'll have no more shares of NTNX. I'm pretty much all in on TGTX right now. I have NTNX on my list of stocks to re-enter if the price is right. I think we're just seeing some consolidation here. My sense was $63ish was the high after ER. I think Rajiv has done a good job running the company, but he's got to work on increasing credibility with investors. Still not happy what happened with 3rd quarter earnings. That dump should have never happened.

Yes, Dell and Nutanix are working close together for a AHV certified Dell appliance, I have heard. And they already have the Dell XC line. And, Dell and Nutanix have jointly announced the support (in the near future) of Powerflex with Nutanix AHV.

Sometimes I'm amazed what I overlook in reading articles. I was rereading the CRN article last Feb about Dell cancelling the VMW GTM agreement at once (2 years before official expiration) after the Broadcom acquisition. It states that the Dell channel accounting for 40% of VMW sales, that is $7 billion! Subsequently Dell and NTNX cozied up and started working together. Now, not all that $5b is going to flow to NTNX, of course, but even small portion would be a meaningful amount for NTNX, particularly when you combine that with a recent article referring research that half of VMW customers weigh alternatives. So you have now the demand side cratering as well as the 'supply' (GTM channel) side to stop pushing VMW---that's a double whammy. Dell may even turn to NTNX as VxRail replacement, just like CSCO terminated HyperFlex. Maybe someone with more knowledge on product strategy level can chime in what is realistic?
Today is a technical non-event. Down 2.8% on 200,000 less shares traded than yesterday. In addition, there's only one distribution day in the last ten trading days.

Dippie re: regulatory approval for takeover of NTNX, you mentioned a concern that an acquisition of NTNX might be blocked due to the difficulty of getting regulatory approval. I'm sure you have seen the article from Silicon Angle. Note that the graphic includes a title "Alternatives to VMWare respond in droves".  I see 10 competitors in the space, which doesn't even include Nutanix. Approval wouldn't be a problem IMO. This is not an AT&T and T-Mobile situation. Regardless, I still don't see an acquisition in the cards until Nutanix establishes a stronger execution pattern, which would justify a higher premium.

Jackie is not off base with ONE possibility in her last post (9:30am Central). How executives manage the Street is critical to their long term approach to potential stock price appreciation. They should tamp down exuberance whether it's due to the price itself heating up or analysts' expectations. Under guide and over perform is good strategy. However, if it was due to something fundamentally altering product acceptance in the industry that's a whole other ballgame. You fundamentalists can better address that than I.

Of course they used to own most of VMWare. One would assume they have good institutional knowledge of the space and some (perhaps many) customers who they can sell competing products to. One can be sure that Dell does not want to sell anything from Broadcom. It could be a nice channel and one that can source big deals.I would not expect Dell to acquire Nutanix. They don't have enough cash on hand for something like that, and they had trouble with debt when they owned VMWare, which part of the reason they divested, so I wouldn't expect them to finance an acquisition. All-stock is possible of course. The response of the street to companies making acquisitions at a premium is often to punish the acquiring company's stock, which would have the immediate effect of lowering the acquisition price for NTNX shareholders.

I used to think they would have been acquired in 2023, but under the present circumstances I think it's not happening soon. An acquisition could blunt their message of FUD vs VMWare, as NTNX would be in the same boat of uncertainty. Also the CEO has a get-rich contract that only triggers if the stock is above $70-80-90, which at this point seems rich, certainly for the upper two targets. I might be wrong but I think they will simply have to execute for several more quarters at least in order to get the kind of valuation that would justify selling the company for a premium.

Even though I put zero belief in your voodoo charts I did decide to Google it:"Despite its ominous name, the death cross is not a market milestone worth dreading. Market history suggests it tends to precede a near-term rebound with above-average returns."

For anyone wanting to look up (Google) what a death cross refers to on a stock's chart, it just took place on NTNX's. I would consider the strong possibility that the price will depreciate from here continuing its downtrend. Strap on your seat belt.

Just reading through the Generation Investment Management filing, the filing was triggered because of sales activity on 7/24. I suspect that was the last day they sold. The price started to recover right after that. It looks like they were selling from 7/11 to 7/24. So, it certainly does explain the decline in share price we saw during that time. These were not sales prior to 6/30. They have been selling over previous quarters, so my guess is these were planned sales to scale out. Maybe they are done selling and wanted to rebalance. I don't know. It could also be that they realize this is Bain's show now. Is it just a mere coincidence that Generation completes their sales by 7/24 and Bain gets their shares on 7/29? Interesting, don't you think? I also find it strange that the short interest as of the last report was 4,982,111. Generation sold 4,619,101 shares. Did someone cover?

Interesting but not great news that they sold those shares and had the effect of cratering the stock as much as it did. It also shows they are a weak hand and still have a lot of shares they can sell, such as on the next increase in price.
For the quarter ending June 30 I'll assume. GIM, smart move. They I'm sure know how to incorporate a chart.

Generation Investment Management filed their 13G/A form today showing they reduced their holdings to 12,530,227 shares. This represents a reduction of 4,619,101 shares or 26.77% of what they had previously reported.
